Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Time-resolved Studies of the Oxygen Evolving Complex of Photosystem II
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemistry of Life Processes Program and the Molecular Biophysics Program are funding Dr. Yulia Pushkar of Purdue University for research towards a detailed mechanism for photosynthesis, the process by which plants produce substances such as sugars from carbon dioxide, water and sunlight. The understanding of this key life process can advance the development of alternative energy sources through the design of better water-splitting catalysts that enable artificial photosynthesis. The work employs various physical measurements to determine the molecular details of this important process in real time and, as such, is at the interface of physics, chemistry and the biological sciences. Consequently, the broader impact of the research is also on several scientific areas including bioinorganic chemistry and molecular biophysics. Additionally, the work has consequences on science education at the high school level through the involvement of the research team in the design of lesson modules about photosynthesis that high school science teachers can adopt and use. Inquiry-based educational modules that incorporate the results of the research are developed for the "Physics of the Green Leaf" program.

The research is focused on the study of the light-induced function of the oxygen evolving complex (OEC) in Photosystem II. The light-induced water splitting by the Mn4Ca cluster of the oxygen evolving complex is a fundamental biological process that sustains our biosphere. Laser pump X-ray probe time-resolved X-ray emission and X-ray absorption spectroscopy are used to monitor changes in the electronic structure of the OEC in real time during catalysis. Transient intermediates in Photosystem II protein are trapped by ultra-fast freeze-quenching and their structure is characterized using the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) method. The research aims are to determine aspects of both the dynamics of the change in electronic structure and the geometry of the manganese cluster and, when combined with DFT calculations, to provide details of the mechanism of catalytic water splitting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oxygenic photosynthesis accomplishes the conversion of water and carbon dioxide to carbohydrates and molecular oxygen. The deceptively simple reaction of water splitting into protons, electrons and molecular oxygen requires one of the most complicated biochemical mechanisms evolved on Earth. Oxygen Evolving Complex is a catalytic center inside a protein whether this reaction occurs with energy input from the sunlight. This catalytic center contains four Mn ions and one Ca bound in the cluster.

Under this proposal we used sophisticated spectroscopic techniques, including X-ray spectroscopy and electron paramagnetic resonance, to study structure and function of the oxygen evolving on its natural time scale (microseconds). Students prepared samples enriched with Photosystem II protein from a supermarket spinach. Highly active samples were used for analysis. Critical portion of experimental work took place at the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory. Undergraduate students involved in this project (nine over the time of proposal) had an opportunity to travel to and conduct experiments at the synchrotron. Analysis of spectroscopic results was enhanced by high-level density functional calculations to reveal energies of different intermediates and spin configurations / spin density distributions. To better understand and more precisely interpret the spectroscopic signals of the oxygen evolving complex we also conducted studies of Mn based model compounds. Some of these had Mn4 cubanes while other had just single Mn ion with Mn=O moiety expected to be active in the O-O bond formation.

Accomplished research is at the cutting edge of modern X-ray spectroscopy and utilized novel spectroscopic approaches and unique facilities such as a 3rd generation synchrotron source and a free electron X-ray laser. We studied one of the most X-ray-damage-sensitive and very dilute (ppm range in terms of the metal content) metalloprotein on the real time scale of the catalytic process – a task deemed impossible only a few years ago. The developed TR X-ray methodology is broadly applicable and can be adopted for analysis of the electronic structure and dynamics in other metalloproteins. Our results uncovered details of the most sought out catalytic process in modern chemistry/biophysics.

Following projects were accomplished:

1) Photosystem II protein preparation and in lab characterization by Uv-vis, O2 evolution assay and EPR.

2) Determination of the Photosystem II OEC (Mn4Ca cluster) structure at room temperature and comparison with low temperature structure, analysis of structural disorder/flexibility at room temperature.

3) Analysis of multiple relevant Mn based OEC models by X-ray absorption and X-ray emission methods, comparison with OEC electronic structure and spectroscopic responses.

4) Development of technology for time resolved X-ray absorption and X-ray emission experimentation.

5) Time resolved analysis of Kok cycle with microsecond time resolution.

6) Development of the new type of XES spectrometer and sample delivery systems for time-resolved X-ray emission spectroscopy.

7) Experimentation at free electron laser. Data analysis and data modeling for XES data obtained at free electron laser.

8) DFT modeling of the oxygen evolving complex geometries, catalytic intermediates, magnetic couplings, spin state and its catalytic mechanism. 

This fundamental knowledge will allow for design and implementation of an artificial photosynthesis concept for CO2 neutral sun-light powered energy production. New knowledge on the function of the oxygen evolving complex (OEC) of the photosystem II discovered under this proposal will be used to design improved systems for artificial photosynthesis. Artificial photosynthesis, ones implemented, will affect lives of people by delivering CO2 neutral, renewable energy. This technology will also minimize effects of human activities in regards to climate change.

Nine undergraduate students received hands on training in research at the interface of Physics, Biology and Chemistry. Most of these students traveled to Advanced Photon Source and participated in data collection at synchrotron.

Three graduate students and two postdoctoral associates in Physics performed research and received training while participating in this project. Two graduate students attended beamtime at free electron laser, LCLS, Stanford Linear Accelerator Laboratory. The research resulted in publication of 9 peer-reviewed papers, two PhD theses, and 25 presentations at conferences or seminars.

PI integrated results of her research activities into the large undergraduate classes such as Modern Mechanics for engineers and General Physics for biology and pre-med students.

High school student conducted PSII preparation from supermarket spinach in PI laboratory.

Girls at Crown Point High School learn about lasers and diffraction by measuring hair thickness. PI group contributed experiment and description. Presentation to the class was done by a graduate student.
